metadata.title: Hydrocephalus, Normal Pressure
description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is a buildup of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) that results in an enlargement of the brain ventricles without an increase in intracranial pressure (ICP)(15)
NPH can be idiopathic or secondary(7,15) –Idiopathic NPH (INPH) tends to affect older adults, whereas secondary NPH can occur at any age
NPH is thought to account for about 5% of all cases of dementia and is one of the few causes of dementia that is potentially treatable(2)

The prevalence of probable INPH was 0.2% in older adults aged 70–79 years and 5.9% in those aged 80 years and older in a large population-based  study conducted in Sweden.(3) The number of persons with INPH is probably higher than the number of patients currently being treated(3)
In extended-care  facilities, the prevalence of NPH might be as high as 14%(2)

ICD-10 codes.G91.2: normal-pressure hydrocephalus (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: It is important that clinicians are aware that NPH frequently is misdiagnosed; physicians might believe the patient has another neurological condition (e.g., Parkinson’s disease), as the symptoms are very similar.(7)Also, it is possible for NPH to coexist with other forms of dementia/diseases (e.g., Alzheimer’s disease)(15,16)

Generally, symptoms of NPH develop insidiously over many months.(16)The severity of signs/symptoms varies among patients –Gait impairment,(2)which has been described as motor apraxia of gait in the absence of sensory or motor weakness(5) -Unsteady gait is common(2,15) -Wide base of support is often observed(2,15) -Looks as if “feet are glued to the floor” as the individual walks(2) -The initial symptom of NPH typically is gait impairment(15)  -See Relevant tests and measures , below, for more information regarding gait impairments –Balance impairment(15,16) –Impaired regulation of urination(2,15,16) –Cognitive impairment(2) -Apparent reduction in the ability to process thoughts, mental slowing -Impaired attention and concentration, forgetfulness
Clinicians often refer to the “triad of symptoms” of NPH(7) –Gait impairment –Urinary incontinence (or related symptoms) –Cognitive impairment
See Medical management , below, for types of shunts used to manage NPH Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: If NPH is suspected in a patient who presents for evaluation via direct access or has seen a physician but a condition other than NPH has been diagnosed, the clinician should refer the patient to his or her primary care physician or neurologist for consultation

causes: INPH–Cases of NPH without a known cause are classified as INPH(15,16)
Secondary NPH–Meningitis(2,15)–Traumatic brain injury (TBI)/head trauma(2,15)–Subarachnoid hemorrhage(2,15)–History of brain surgery(2)
pathogenesis: Theorized sequence of events behind NPH:–There might be a decrease in CSF absorption(15)–A slow dilation of the ventricles within the brain occurs as a result of the increased CSF;(1) it appears there is a briefincrease in intracranial pressure (beyond normal range, which is typically 7–15  mmHg in supine) during this buildup ofCSF, ultimately leading to the change in size of the ventricles(15)–The increased size of the ventricles places stress on the brain(1)–Physiological manifestations (e.g., gait impairments) of NPH present(2)
Altered compliance (elasticity) of the ventricle walls and/or increased viscosity of the CSF might have roles in thepathogenesis of NPH
risk factors: Increased head circumference might indicate a congenital component to idiopathic NPH
The conditions listed above under Causes  for secondary NPH would also be considered risk factors

overall contraindications precautions: Shunt complications(19) Infection in or around the shunt: the clinician should monitor for signs of infection (e.g., fever, irritability) Fracture of the shunt: monitor for a return to pretreatment symptom status, which might indicate shunt malfunction The patient might experience seizures following surgery: appropriate precautions should be taken Underdrainage: patient condition post shunt insertion does not improve or improves only slightly –Bedridden patients should sit upright regularly to avoid complications with underdrainage. If sitting/upright positions are not tolerated, the physician should decide if adjustment of pressure settings is warranted “Siphoning” (overdrainage) –Can occur when gravity (patient sitting or standing) causes more CSF fluid to exit the ventricles than desired  –Symptoms -Headaches -V omiting –Shunts now have specific components that were implemented to prevent this phenomenon Other signs of shunt complications (potentially indicating infection, bleeding, or obstruction)(20) –Vision disturbances –Headaches –Reduced coordination –Tiredness Patients with an implanted shunt are not generally restricted in their daily activities but might have restrictions placed on an activity requiring high levels of physical exertion. Check the surgeon’s specific orders Any activity or condition that increases intra-abdominal  pressure can result in transient worsening of symptoms (e.g., Valsalva maneuver, constipation) and should be addressed or avoided
Individuals with NPH are at risk for falls; follow facility protocol for fall risk
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: If NPH is suspected in a patient who presents for evaluation via direct access or has seen a physician but a condition other than NPH has been diagnosed, the clinician should refer the patient to his or her primary care physician or neurologist for consultation

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Etiology of illness -Does the patient have a history of falls? -When did symptoms begin? -Symptoms of secondary NPH may be delayed from the time of the original insult to the brain; obtain a detailed medical history -When was NPH diagnosed and what were the original symptoms? -Have the symptoms progressed? If yes, describe how -Has the patient experienced any complications?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Shunt placement; types include(17) ventriculoperitoneal (VP) ventriculopleural ventriculoatrial Improved shunting modalities and novel shunt materials with valve adjustments have improved the precision of the shunting procedures(10) In a study conducted in Germany, researchers found that implantation of a VP shunt was a safe procedure that improved the symptoms of74% of patients with INPH in the longer term(4) Patients in whom VP shunts had been placed had yearly follow-up  examinations for at least 6 years Authors of a preliminary study in Poland investigated brain perfusion 12 days before and 36 days after VP shunt placement in 16 patients with INPH. Improvement in perfusion was observed in 62.5% of patients(8) Improvement was measured by SPECT scans and was found to be global or regional in different cerebral areas, with prevalence in the frontal lobes Authors of a study in China assessed 35 patients with disorders of consciousness following subarachnoid hemorrhage who had undergone VP shunting for NPH(14) Treatment group was compared to 16 matched controls made up of similar patients who declined VP shunting Data included clinical examinations, rehabilitation assessments, and CT scans. All patients with disorders of consciousness underwent neurorehabilitation. Consciousness was measured on the Glasgow Outcome Scale  The Glasgow Outcome Scale scores were significantly higher in the VP shunting group compared to the nontreatment  control group 3 months post shunting and/or rehabilitation treatments
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed, if any; are they being taken? There is no known evidence that NPH can be effectively treated with medication(2)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnosis requires a combination of clinical, neuropsychological, and diagnostic testing(15)
blood work to rule out vitamin B6/B12 deficiency

A CT scan or MRI of the brain is necessary but does not alone establish a diagnosis of NPH. Primary radiographic evidence for NPH includes ventriculomegaly (enlargement) of the lateral ventricles that is not attributed to other structural defects. CSF flow changes can also be identified(7)
Currently, no clinical or neuroradiological techniques have been validated to distinguish INPH from similar diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease(10,11)

Authors of a study in France compared MRI and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) scans of 30 patients (18 with Alzheimer’s disease and 12 with suspected NPH). Although both conditions involve CSF disorders, significant
differences were found in whitematter  characteristics(12)
Researchers in Japan investigated voxel-based morphometry (VBM) techniques for identifying and quantifying the disproportionate distribution of CSF spaces in patients with NPH(13)
VBM images were recorded of 19 patients with NPH, 24 patients with Alzheimer’s disease, 18 patients with Parkinson’s disease, and 14 healthy individuals

Analysis of VBM-based  images quantified a disproportionate distribution of the CSF space, thereby differentiating, with excellent sensitivity and specificity, the patients with NPH from the patients with Alzheimer’s disease and Parkinson’s disease and the healthy individuals
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Does the patient report any aggravating or easing factors?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document the location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Nature of symptoms -Document nature of symptoms -In patients with INPH -If urinary incontinence develops, it generally does so late in the progression of the condition. However, heightened frequency and/or urgency might develop early on(2) -Fecal incontinence can also occur;(2) it also generally occurs late in the progression of the condition -Difficulty carrying out everyday activities might be a sign of cognitive decline early in the course of the diseasegait instability, cognitive changes, and incontinence. Typically, gait instability is an earlier symptom, followed by cognitive changes and incontinence. Initially, the patient might complain of urinary urgency as opposed to incontinence. Although many patients exhibit this triad, all three symptoms do not have to be present for the diagnosis of NPH(7)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Where appropriate, use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to the physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any respiratory compromise? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis General inquiry Does the patient have a history of meningitis(15) TBI or brain trauma(15) subarachnoid hemorrhage(15) brain surgery(2)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient or caregiver about other problems, including diabetes, hypertension, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she might be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational activities? Has there been a change in participation level? Does the patient work? What type of work? Does the patient have a history of alcohol abuse?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document any reported limitations in ADLs
social and occupational history.living environment: Number of floors and stairs in the home, with whom the patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home and if any modifications are necessary

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –Circumferential measurements of the head should be obtained -Macrocephaly could signal the presence of congenital hydrocephalus that only began to affect the patient in adulthood -Concern arises when the head circumference is > -57.5 cm in women -59 cm in men
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient utilize any assistive or adaptive devices? If so, are they appropriate?  –Impaired gait and postural responses potentially affect the ability to safely use a standard walker. Assess the need for an alternative device
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Impaired balance is common in individuals with INPH(2,23) –Disequilibrium is typically worse with eyes closed, but NPH patients need to stand with a broad base(2)even with eyes open –Turning might be particularly challenging and patient may have hesitation(15) –The Tinetti Assessment Tool may be used to assess balance and gait; please see Special tests specific to diagnosis , below –The Berg Balance Scale might be used
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Impairment of gait is common and is usually the initial symptom(15) -Broad-based  stance is common -Step length is reduced -Step height is diminished, giving the appearance that the feet are stuck to the floor (“magnetic” or “glued down”) -Clearance during the swing is impaired -Feet appear externally rotated -Reduced velocity of gait -Hip counter rotation is reduced -Arm swing can be reduced -Difficulty turning or en bloc  turning (turning that requires 3 or more steps to turn 180 degrees)(5) -Difficulty initiating ambulation(2) –Protocols for insertion of a lumbar drain include the use of standardized tests and measures to assess gait and balance before and throughout the drainage period. Test results can be used to determine whether a patient might benefit from shunt surgery(23,25) -Tests commonly used include -Timed Up and Go (TUG) test -Tinetti Performance Oriented Mobility Assessment (POMA) -10-meter  walk test (10MWT) -When the results of the Tinetti, TUG test, 10MWT, and/or cognitive testing do not improve after a lumbar puncture, the patient would not be recommended for shunt placement –Further research is required to validate balance and gait assessment in this patient population to determine if the prediction of shunt outcome is possible using gait assessment.(5)Researchers who conducted a study in Italy proposed an instrumented gait analysis for a pre-and post-assessment  of a tap test in NPH(9) -Gait assessments were performed before and 2 to 4 hours after tap test utilizing multichannel recording systems which -Heel contact duration (left and right), flat-foot  contact duration (left and right), push-off  duration (left and right), swing duration (left and right), double-limb  support duration, as a percentage of the gait cycle and dynamic ROM (left and right) -Data from the 11 parameters were assessed and combined into a single quantitative score. Gait velocity was also measured and analyzedtap test responders (n = 22, 9 of whom were shunted) and not suitable for shunt (n = 38, 4 of whom were shunted). In the tap test responders group, 9 of 9 patients improved after shunt. In the not suitable for shunt group, 3 of 4 patients did not improve. Gait velocity improved in 53% of responders and 37% of patients not suitable for shunt  -New methods might be applicable for selecting tap test responders and quantifying objective improvements. Gait velocity alone is not sufficient to reliably assess tap test effects. Results are limited by small sample size; additional research is warranted –In later stages of NPH the motor deficit is often worsened by coinciding cognitive deficits (e.g., dementia)(15) –The Dynamic Gait Index might be used to assess safety while walkingAssess joint integrity as indicated by symptoms and patient presentation Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –There is generally a combination of motor deficits –Assess postural righting reflexes -Often impaired or absent –Assess muscle tone and coordination -There is often an increased tone and brisk tendon reflexes in the lower limbs, but an absence of weakness or incoordination –Fine motor and upper extremity coordination might be impaired(6)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess muscle strength. Manual muscle testing (MMT) is not considered valid in the presence of abnormal tone or coordination
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess ROM and flexibility as indicated by symptoms and patient presentation
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexesAssess ADLs and note impairments; please see  Special tests specific to diagnosis , below
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing (e.g., light touch) should be normal in patients with NPH
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to the diagnosis –Physical and occupational therapy outcome measures used in current practice may be useful in evaluating change in patients with NPH(15) -Berg Balance Scale -Functional Reach Test -TUG
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem-solving) –The dementia observed with NPH is described as fronto-subcortical(22)(vs cortical dementia, which has different causes [e.g., Alzheimer’s disease]) -Fronto-subcortical  dementia refers to a pattern of mental decline characterized by(22) -executive dysfunction -psychomotor slowing, slowed mental processing -mood swings, especially apathy –Instruments that might be useful in assessing the patient’s dementia(22) -Wechsler Memory Scale–Revised -The Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE)

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; if inpatient, follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at the bedside. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Impairments in gait, balance, functional ability, and ADLs
assessment plan of care.rule out: Many conditions need to be ruled out before making a diagnosis of NPH; these include, but are not limited to, the following: Alzheimer’s disease(2) Parkinson’s disease(2) Dementia with Lewy bodies(2) Subdural hematoma Benign or malignant tumor  Combinations of conditions that affect gait, cognition, and urinary continence such as dementia, prostate disease, and vestibular dysfunction
prognosis: The natural course of INPH is symptom progression over time, with worsening in balance, gait, and cognitive symptoms. This deterioration is only partially reversible(6) –In a study conducted in Sweden, outcomes in patients who waited for more than 6 months before surgery were compared to outcomes in patients who waited less than 3 months(6) -Delayed patients deteriorated significantly during their wait for surgery. The magnitude of change after surgery was similar in both groups, but since the symptoms of the delayed patients had worsened their final outcomes were significantly poorer
With current diagnostic and therapeutic techniques, 80–90%  of patients have improved symptoms after CSF shunting(16)
Generally, the earlier the diagnosis is made (with subsequent medical management), the better the prognosis(1)

The ability to predict the response to neurosurgery in NPH has yet to be accomplished. Combining different neuroimaging sequences as well as quantitative and qualitative parameters could provide better diagnosis and treatment(11)
The clinician should be aware that shunting is not successful in all patients and surgical outcomes vary(2)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Neurologist Social worker Occupational and speech therapy as indicated Cognitive psychology Nutritionist if secondary to diabetes or hypertension Nursing for management of bowel and bladder issues
treatment summary: No studies evaluating the efficacy of rehabilitation interventions for this condition were identified . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Impaired gait, balance, and functional mobility, increased risk for fallsImprove gait, balance, and functional mobilityTherapeutic strategies _ Physical therapy interventions aimed at addressing specific impairments as noted in the evaluation _ _Progress each unique patient as appropriate and indicatedImplement a home program to support the therapeutic interventions utilized during treatment sessions as appropriate and indicated. Educate family/caregivers about fall risk and home modifications to prevent falls Impaired ability to complete ADLsImprove ability to complete ADLsTherapeutic strategies _ Interventions aimed at addressing specific impairments as noted in the evaluation, refer to occupational therapy as indicated and appropriateProgress each unique patient as appropriate and indicatedImplement a home program to support the therapeutic interventions utilized during treatment sessions as appropriate and indicated  Potential for shunt complicationsMonitor for shunt complications; patient and/or caregivers independent in monitoring for shunt complicationsPatient education _ Patient and family or caregiver education on monitoring for shunt complications. Please see Overall

improved gait, balance, and functional m: TUG test, Tinetti total score, Tinetti balance, Tinetti gait, DGI, Berg Balance Scale, gait speed, number of steps taken inturning
improved ability to complete adls: FIM toilet transfer, FIM lower body dressing

maintenance or prevention: The patient should follow up with his or her physician as directed by the physician
Periodic brain imaging may be used to monitor overdrainage 6–12  months post shunt surgery until the patient’s condition is stable(16)
patient education: Hydrocephalus Association, https://www.hydroassoc.org/ Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
